bibl.title: Letter from Guy Charles Moore Godfrey to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 19, 1899

div1.p: Godfrey writes a confidential letter requesting the reassignment of Dr. Alden and Dr. Jackson, who do not work well with him.

div1.head: Letter from Guy Charles Moore Godfrey to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 19, 1899
div1.opener:
Confidential
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
Pinar del Rio Bks. Cuba
Dec. 19, 1899
My dear Major Kean,
div1.p:
I wanted very
much to see you this week, but as
Dr. Alden has gone away I do
not care to go and leave only
one surgeon here to do the work.
I wanted to speak to you about
Dr. Alden, among other things I think
the United States could very well dis-
pense with his services for the fol-
lowing reasons, he lacks moral
strength and professionally is for that
reason incompetent to handle severe
cases - such as that of Pot. Chase who
died here. Again he is not sincere
and while outwardly professing the
utmost friendship, etc., professes the
opposite when he thinks it can be
done without being detected. He is a
man with a fine address and I was de-
cieved at first as many thus are, but
he is not trustworthy in any way. I
would not care to have him as my
assistant here with no one else to
rely on. In addition to his gossiping
with other people he gossips with the
men going to them with his complaints
instead of coming to me. I am quite
satisfied that he made some com-
plaint to Major Edmunds while he
was here and I want to see the Major
too and have my little say although
that would not be a necessity I am
sure. I have endeavored to treat
all of my assistants with equal
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
Confidential
consideration and to equally divide the
labor. Several of the things I have told
you I have found out since Dr. Alden
left here. I could tell many others
if I chose to gossip. Mrs. A. is a
trouble-maker and her absence would be
a distinct blessing and relieve much trouble
in the female ranks from which I re-
main distinctly neutral and Mrs. G likewise.

Dr. Jackson is a good surgeon and physi-
cian I believe. However, the day he left
here he made the remark in the presence
of some of the men (but not to me) that if he could
get the ears of the people at headquar-
ters he would have the inspector down
here. I do not believe that Maj. Edmunds
visit, however, was due to any such repre-
sentations. I find that with one loyal
assistant here now that I can get along
much better than with four; two of whom are
not. I believe Dr. Jackson is a good man
for an A. A. Surgeon and that he is good
professionally but after his threat in the pres-
cence of witnesses I naturally do not think
his prescence here could be of much value to
me. Therefore I hope you will order him
somewhere else, if convenient. If not I will
do the best I can.

I made a discovery in the surgery line
the other day. By raising the arm backwards
and inwards from the shoulder joint so
that the elbow will be back of the head the
circulation of the axillary artery is entirely shut
off. The position varies with the individual
but works in every case. One fourth of an inch
difference will close or open the circulation.
I will report later with photographs. Dr. Press-
oull and I operate nearly every day as I have
charge of the surgery ward.
div1.closer: Loyally Yours Gen C. M. Godfriy.
